title: 112_hr984
content: The "Health Care Waiver Fairness Act of 2011" establishes a waiver process under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act for certain provisions. The "Health Care Waiver Fairness Act of 2011" establishes a waiver process for health plans, employers, individuals, or entities to seek exemption from certain requirements under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, including maintaining minimum essential coverage and reporting health insurance coverage. The "Health Care Waiver Fairness Act of 2011" establishes a waiver process for health plans, employers, individuals, or entities to seek exemption from certain requirements under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, including maintaining minimum essential coverage and reporting health insurance coverage. Additionally, it includes provisions such as automatic enrollment for employees of large employers, notice to employees, shared responsibility for employers regarding health coverage, reporting on health insurance coverage, free choice vouchers, and regulations on grandfathered health plans. The "Health Care Waiver Fairness Act of 2011" establishes a waiver process for seeking exemption from certain requirements under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The waiver process includes providing public notice and guidance for submission of waiver requests, identifying specific requirements to be waived, and describing how the imposition of each requirement would be affected. The "Health Care Waiver Fairness Act of 2011" establishes a waiver process for seeking exemption from certain requirements under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Waiver requests accompanied by a statement showing significant decrease in access to coverage or increase in costs will be deemed approved. Authorities will publish data on waiver requests, and approved waivers will be treated accordingly. The "Health Care Waiver Fairness Act of 2011" establishes a waiver process for exemptions from certain requirements under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Approved waivers will not apply to entities after approval, and other exemptions in the Act will still be valid. The term "applicable authority" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, or the Secretary of Labor in specific cases. The "Health Care Waiver Fairness Act of 2011" establishes a waiver process for exemptions from certain requirements under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of the Treasury are responsible for administering specific provisions of the Act. References to requirements under this title include amendments made by this Act. A public awareness campaign is funded by the Prevention and Public Health Fund. The Prevention and Public Health Fund allocates $50,000,000 for a public awareness campaign on the waiver process. Establishment of waiver process under Subtitle G.
